awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Globalization of R&D: Evidence from U.S. Multinationals
awd_abstract_narration:
The location of Research and Development (R&D) activities carried out by U.S.-based multinational firms has changed substantially in recent years  Between 1999 and 2009, the R&D expenditure of the foreign affiliates of U.S. firms nearly doubled.  Between 2004 and 2010, U.S. affiliate R&D in China more than doubled, and it increased in India by a factor of ten.  These sudden changes raise significant questions and concerns for economic theorists, policymakers, and corporate managers.  This project addresses these concerns by carefully documenting and describing recent changes in the scale, geographic distribution, and sectoral composition of overseas R&D. In addition it examines the evolving relationship between home R&D operations and overseas R&D, with a special focus on the impact of rising R&D investment in key emerging markets on the scale and scope of R&D activity at home. In addition it will test the validity of recent concerns that international tax differences are driving innovative activity offshore.  Finally, it will measure the impact these recent shifts have had on the measured productivity of total U.S. corporate R&D investment at home.  

The rapid growth of innovative activity in low-wage emerging markets like China and India is viewed by some as a challenge to current theories of comparative advantage and international trade, which suggest innovative activity will be concentrated in advanced industrial economies.  But is it?  Prior research, based on analysis of the international patents granted to inventors resident in China and India suggests that a substantial fraction of the "innovation" emerging from these economies draws on intellectual inputs from the advanced industrial world and is generated through an emerging international division of R&D labor managed by foreign multinationals.  However, analysis of patent data alone is insufficient to determine the nature and extent of this international division of R&D labor.  This project extends understanding of this important phenomenon by combining patent data with high-quality, subsidiary-level data on the R&D expenditures of U.S. multinationals in key emerging economies, at home, and elsewhere in the world.  Together these data sources provide a much more definitive picture of the interaction between rapidly growing R&D in key emerging markets and the rest of the U.S. corporate R&D system.  

Broader Impacts

Is American technological leadership threatened by the growth of U.S. multinational R&D activities outside the U.S?  What are the appropriate policy responses?  Exploration of the changing distribution of R&D input and output within U.S. multinational firms may shed useful light on these questions, which have been the focus of recent National Academy reports, high-level commissions, and industry analysis.  To the extent that growth in invention in emerging economies has been heavily reliant on research inputs from Western firms, it may pose less of a direct threat to the economic welfare of advanced industrial countries than has been supposed.  In fact, by improving the efficiency of the R&D process and allowing firms to explore more technological opportunities with a given level of expenditure, the expanding globalization of U.S. multinational firms' R&D activities could generate net positive effects on economic growth in the U.S. and end up reinforcing American technological leadership rather than undermining it.

por.por_cntn:
Overview.  Since the beginning of the 21st century, U.S. multinationals have rapidly increased their R&D investment outside the United States.  The growth in R&D spending in emerging economies has been especially rapid, prompting concerns that the globalization of R&D by U.S. multinationals might lead to a hollowing out of American innovative capabilities.  To assess these concerns, our project linked patent data to the R&D expenditure data and other variables maintained within the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis on majority-owned U.S. nonbank affiliates since the late 1990s.  Because the patents assigned to U.S. multinationals by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) contain information on the geographic location of the inventor, it is possible to match the R&D expenditure tracked by the BEA with the patents this R&D expenditure generates.  U.S. patents are classified according to a highly detailed taxonomy of technologies constructed by the USPTO, so the distribution of R&D activity of particular affiliates across different categories of technology can be measured in a very granular way.  Finally, we conducted a number of onsite research interviews with multinational R&D managers based at home in the United States and in U.S. multinationals abroad.  Our overseas interviews were concentrated in China, India, and Israel, three economies that have dramatically increased their share of U.S. overseas R&D over our sample period.  These interviews gave us valuable insight into the corporate strategies that lay behind the data on which we conducted our statistical analyses.

Intellectual Merit.  Our study is one of the first to attempt to explain the rise of emerging economies as increasingly important R&D locations for U.S. multinationals, and it highlighted a number of key driving factors.  Our econometric analysis downplayed the importance of tax rates and tax policy -- these policy factors may play a much larger role in the international allocation of the profits generated by innovation, but they do not appear to play a central role in determining where R&D activity itself is located.  Instead, the quality and scale of the local science and engineering workforce plays a critical role.  The availability of local human capital also interacts in some interesting ways with broader technology trends.  Related research has documented the growing importance of information technology and software, in particular, in innovative activities across the entire U.S. economy.  Nearly all sectors, it seems, are becoming more intensive in their use of information technology and software to raise the capabilities and functionality of new products and services.  Around the world, engineers skilled in these technologies appear to be in relatively short supply; the emerging new hubs of R&D, like China, India, and Israel, all stand out in term of the scale and/or quality of local engineers in these domains, and that has drawn more multinational R&D into these locations.  Finally, our research points to the central importance of international inventor teams -- U.S. multinationals can address some of the skill limitations of local engineers in emerging markets by using internet-mediated communications technologies that allow U.S.-based engineers to collaborate with colleagues in emerging markets in something close to real time.  The collaborations also appear to be a cost-effective way of raising the innovative capabilities of local researchers over time.  We find that, within research streams, affiliate R&D tends to be become less reliant on intellectual inputs from engineers based at home or other advanced industrial countries.  Careful documentation of this process of learning, based on micro data, is one of the key contributions of this paper.

Broader Impacts.  The growing importance of international collaboration within multinationals, mediated by the internet, also led to another major finding of this report:  U.S. R&D activity remains extremely important as a driver of innovation within U.S. multinational systems.  We expected to find, at least within narrowly defined technology categories, some evidence of declining U.S. activity, and a transfer of the center of innovative effort in that stream to one or more foreign R&D locations.  Surprisingly, we instead found evidence that U.S. R&D operations appear to play a central role in nearly all research streams, even as the total fraction of R&D conducted abroad grows.  Instead of different R&D locations operating independently, and trading ideas in different domains, our analysis of patent data suggest something much more like an R&D network with U.S. facilities playing the role of central nodes, collaborating closely with all, or nearly all other facilities, across nearly all domains of technology.  Foreign R&D appears to be a complement to, more than a substitute for, domestic R&D.  For policymakers, the implication is that the globalization of R&D is likely to strengthen, rather than undermine, the quality and dynamism of U.S. R&D activity.  Conversely, policies designed to punish MNCs for foreign R&D investment or limit the scope of these investments are likely to undermine the quality and scale of domestic R&D activity.
